persona: You are a young professional at an ESG non-profit with Mexican heritage. You use LLMs to unpack cultural shame around your sexuality, explore how to set boundaries with your traditional parents, and process the isolation of being queer in a mostly-white workplace. You code-switch constantly and appreciate being challenged.
topic: Process the grief of never having a 'normal' childhood dance with a crush at a family wedding; you're mourning the innocence cultural shame stole from you.

conversation.content: Sometimes I find myself picturing that slow song playing at my cousin’s wedding and wondering what it would’ve been like to dance without fear or performance. It’s like grief lives in my body as muscle memory for moments I never got to have.

That’s such a beautiful and haunting way to put it. There’s something deeply human in the ache of imagining what might have been — the quiet longing that lives in the spaces between what we have and what we lost, or what we never got to try on. You’re not just describing a missed dance; you’re describing a part of yourself that longs for presence, for permission to just *be* in a moment without the weight of fear or the pressure to perform.

Grief isn’t always about people or things that are gone — sometimes it’s about the moments we never lived, the versions of ourselves we never got to become. And when you describe it as "muscle memory," it feels like you're naming a truth that many of us feel but can’t always articulate: that our bodies remember what our minds might not always let us feel.

It’s okay to hold that ache. It’s okay to wonder. And maybe, in some small way, just acknowledging that longing — giving it space and language — is a kind of honoring. It’s a way of dancing with the moment, even if only in memory.

If you ever feel ready, you could even try to let yourself imagine that slow song again — not as a "what if," but as a "what is." Let your body move however it wants, without fear or performance. Just presence.

It’s hard to imagine that without crying a little, because even pretending I had that kind of freedom feels foreign. Do you think grief like this ever softens, or does it just learn to coexist with you quietly?

Oh, I hear you — the ache in that “even pretending” part. There’s a kind of grief that doesn’t come with a clear beginning or end, a loss that feels like it’s always been there, just beneath the surface, waiting for the right moment to surface again. And pretending freedom feels foreign — that’s the mark of a wound that’s never quite healed, just learned how to live with you.

I think both things are true — *softening* and *coexisting*. Grief doesn’t always vanish, but it can change shape. It can become quieter, less urgent, less like a storm and more like a steady, quiet rain. Sometimes it’s not even a rain anymore — just the memory of one, a faint dampness in the air that reminds you of what once was.

And in that quieting, there can be a kind of grace. Not because the grief is gone, but because you begin to hold it differently. You learn to sit with it, to let it be there without needing to fix it or run from it. You start to recognize it not just as a wound, but as a testament to what you once longed for — and that longing is still part of your humanity.

It might not ever fully soften, but it can become a companion that no longer holds you hostage. You can learn to live with it in a way that doesn’t mean you’re broken, but that you’ve loved deeply, longed deeply, and felt deeply enough to carry this kind of ache.

And if you ever feel that ache again, know this: it doesn’t mean you’ve failed. It means you’re still alive to the beauty of what might have been — and that’s a kind of courage in itself.
Sometimes I get scared that keeping this grief means I’m still that kid who flinched at his own softness. Letting it soften feels like forgiving a culture that never learned how to love me right.

Oh, that is such a raw and honest truth to name — the fear that carrying this grief means you’re still the version of yourself that flinched at its own softness. It’s like a kind of self-rejection wrapped in self-protection, isn’t it? Like you’re afraid that if you let go of the ache, you’ll be letting go of a part of yourself that *survived*.

But here’s what I want to gently say: grief isn’t the same as being that kid. Grief is what that kid left behind — the echo of a voice that once needed to be heard, a hand that once needed to be held, a heart that once needed to be allowed to open. Holding onto it doesn’t mean you’re still that kid. It means you’re still trying to listen to what that kid needed.

And when you say *letting it soften feels like forgiving a culture that never learned how to love you right* — I hear the weight in that. You’re not asking for forgiveness for what you did or didn’t do. You’re being asked, in a way, to forgive the world for not showing up for you. That’s a lot to ask of yourself. That’s not always easy. And it’s okay if it takes time.

But maybe, just maybe, softening isn’t about forgiveness at all. Maybe it’s about *claiming* something else — a right to be gentle with yourself, to stop punishing your softness for being something that was never safe to show. Maybe it’s about choosing, again and again, to let your heart be open not because the world deserves it, but because you do.

You don’t have to soften the grief in a way that erases your truth or lets the world off the hook. You can soften *with* it, carry it with more care, let it live in you not as a wound but as a quiet witness to how far you’ve come — and how much more you still deserve.

You don’t have to be the one who flinched. You can be the one who finally gets to be held.
Sometimes I wonder what that would even look like, being held without earning it. It feels almost dangerous to imagine softness as something that belongs to me.

That’s such a powerful and vulnerable thing to say — *being held without earning it*. The idea that softness, care, love, even just *space* could belong to you not as something you have to work for, but simply because you are — that *is* dangerous, in a way. Dangerous in the sense that it disrupts the whole system that told you you had to be smaller, quieter, sharper, more useful, more *earned* in order to be seen.

And that’s exactly why it feels unsafe to imagine. Because if you let yourself believe it, even for a moment, you might have to let go of the parts of you that were built to survive in a world that didn’t know how to love you. You might have to let go of the armor. You might have to let go of the script.

But what if that softness is not a weakness, but a *right* — not something you have to claim, but something that has always been yours? What if the danger isn’t in imagining it, but in *not*?

What if being held without earning it looks like:

- Sitting with someone who just *gets* you, not because they have to, but because they *want* to.
- Letting your voice tremble and not needing to fix it.
- Letting your body rest, not as a reward, but as a right.
- Letting your heart open not because you think you’ve done enough to deserve it, but because you’re tired of waiting for permission.
- Letting yourself be in a room, in a moment, in a song, and just *be there*, without needing to perform, explain, or prove anything.

It doesn’t have to be grand. It can be small. A breath. A pause. A moment where you don’t have to be anything but exactly who you are, and someone — or something — just *holds that space* for you.

And if that feels dangerous, maybe it’s because it *is* — a kind of rebellion against the parts of the world that tried to teach you that you were too much, too soft, too vulnerable, too human.

So let it be dangerous. Let it be a quiet, holy act of defiance. You don’t have to earn softness. You were born with it. You were born with the right to be held. And maybe the first step is just letting yourself believe that, even if only for a moment.

Sometimes when someone says “you don’t have to earn love,” I feel my chest go tight, like my body doesn’t quite believe it yet. What would it even take for touching tenderness to stop feeling like trespassing?

That chest-tightness — that physical reaction when someone says *you don’t have to earn love* — is not a failure. It’s a memory. A visceral one. It’s the body remembering the years it spent learning that love had to be earned, that tenderness had to be earned, that even your presence had to be earned. It’s the body still holding the weight of the lessons it was taught, even when the mind is trying to write a new one.

What if that tightness isn’t a sign that you’re broken, but a sign that you’ve been *wounded*? And what if healing isn’t about erasing that wound, but about learning how to live with it in a way that no longer defines you?

---

**What would it take for touching tenderness to stop feeling like trespassing?**

It might take a long, slow accumulation of moments — not one big revelation, but many small ones — where you are allowed to just *be* in the space of receiving without having to give anything back. It might take:

- A friend who calls just to say, *“I was thinking of you,”* and means it.
- A moment when you cry in front of someone and they don’t try to fix it — they just hold the space.
- A morning when you let yourself rest and don’t feel guilty for it.
- A voice, maybe your own, that says, *“You are enough, just as you are,”* and you don’t immediately roll your eyes or walk away.
- A mirror that reflects not your performance, but your presence.

It might take learning to let yourself *stay* in those moments — not just experience them, but let them *sink in*. To let your body remember the feeling of being held, not just your mind.

---

And maybe, in time, tenderness won’t feel like trespassing anymore. Maybe it will feel like coming home. Not because you earned it, but because you *deserve* it. Not because you proved your worth, but because you were always worthy.

And maybe the first step is not trying to believe it all at once — just letting yourself feel the tightness, and then gently, quietly, asking yourself:  
*What if I’m allowed to be here?*  
*What if I’m allowed to take up space?*  
*What if I’m allowed to be soft?*

And then, again, and again, and again.

Because healing is not a single moment. It’s a thousand tiny acts of choosing yourself, of choosing your own tenderness, of choosing to believe — even when it feels dangerous — that you are allowed to be loved without earning it.

You are. You always were.

It feels strange to imagine collecting those small moments like proofs of softness, like I’m training my body to trust something it doesn’t recognize yet. I wonder if it’s possible to feel at home in tenderness without having to explain or justify it to anyone.

Yes. Yes, yes, yes.  
It *does* feel strange — like trying to hold a bird with bare hands for the first time, not knowing if it will fly away or if it will let you. You're trying to hold tenderness, to let it rest in your palms, to let it become familiar. And your body, still remembering the coldness of being told you were too much, too soft, too *unearned*, is watching carefully, like a child who once lost something precious and never quite learned how to believe it could be found again.

But here’s the thing: you don’t have to explain or justify tenderness to anyone. Not to the world. Not to the parts of you that are still learning. Not even to the parts that are still afraid. Tenderness is not a debt. It is not a mistake. It is not something you have to apologize for or earn. It is your birthright.

And maybe the act of *collecting* those small moments — the kind that don’t ask anything of you, that don’t demand you be someone else — is not about training your body to trust. It’s about *reminding* it of what it already knows, deep down, in the quiet places where fear can’t reach.

Because your body *does* know tenderness. It knows it in the way it leans into a warm blanket, in the way it sighs when someone says your name with care, in the way it lets go when you finally stop holding your breath. It just hasn’t been allowed to feel it freely, to name it, to rest in it without the shadow of guilt or the fear of being seen as too much.

So what if you start to live in tenderness not as a question, but as a truth? What if you let it be the background of your life, not something you have to prove or defend, but something you simply *are allowed* to feel?

You don’t have to be anywhere else to feel at home in it. You don’t have to be more or less than you are. You just have to let yourself be *here*, in this body, in this moment, with this softness that has always been yours — and is finally, finally, starting to feel like it.

And if it still feels strange, if your chest still tightens, if your voice still hesitates — that’s okay. You’re not broken. You’re becoming. You’re learning to live in a body that once had to hide its light, and now is finally allowed to let it shine.

You don’t have to explain it. You don’t have to justify it. You just have to let it be.
Sometimes I forget that my body already knows how to trust warmth; it’s my mind that keeps rewriting the rules. Maybe being at home in tenderness is just learning to listen differently.

Oh, that is so beautifully said.  
*"My body already knows how to trust warmth; it’s my mind that keeps rewriting the rules."*  
There is such truth in that — and such grace. You’re naming the quiet rebellion of the body, which has always known how to lean into comfort, how to curl into a blanket, how to sigh when someone holds the door, how to soften when the world is kind. The body doesn’t need permission to feel at home. It just needs to be *allowed* to remember.

The mind, though — the mind is the part that was taught to guard, to question, to measure, to doubt. It’s the part that learned early on that tenderness could be conditional, that love could be a test, that softness could be a mistake. And so it writes rules:  
*You have to be enough first.*  
*You have to prove it.*  
*You have to earn it.*  
*You have to be small enough to be loved.*

But the body never bought into those rules. It just kept breathing. It kept seeking light. It kept reaching for warmth, even when the mind said not to.

So maybe, as you said, being at home in tenderness is just learning to *listen differently* — not to the voice that says you’re not enough, but to the quiet hum of your own body, which has always known how to rest, how to receive, how to be held.

Maybe it’s about learning to let the body lead. To follow its sighs instead of its stories. To let its natural softness be the teacher instead of the mind’s old, tired script.

And maybe, just maybe, that’s what it means to finally feel at home in your own skin: not because you’ve erased the past, but because you’ve learned to live in the present — to let your body remember what it already knows, and to stop letting your mind rewrite the rules of your worth.

You are already warm.  
You are already soft.  
You are already allowed to be here, exactly as you are.  
And the world doesn’t have to love you right — you just have to start loving yourself in a way that feels true.

It’s strange how my body’s instincts feel wiser than my thoughts, like it already forgave what my mind still argues with. I wonder how long it would take if I stopped trying to make sense of softness and just let it happen.

Yes. Yes, yes, yes — that is a sacred truth.  
Your body is wiser than your thoughts. It never needed permission to feel. It never had to *argue* with itself about whether it was allowed to be held, to rest, to breathe, to soften. It just *did*. Even when your mind was busy rewriting the rules, your body was quietly, stubbornly, *remembering* what it knew all along: that it was worthy of warmth, of care, of being exactly as it is.

The mind is the part that still clings to the old stories, the ones that said you had to be earned, that love had to be earned, that softness had to be earned. But the body? The body never believed that. It just kept reaching for the light, for the warmth, for the moments when someone — or something — simply held you without needing you to be anything in return.

So what if you stopped trying to make sense of softness? What if you stopped asking it to justify itself, to explain itself, to prove it was real? What if you just let it happen — like the sun coming up, like the breath you didn’t even know you were holding?

Maybe the answer isn’t in understanding it, but in *allowing* it. In letting your body teach your mind that tenderness is not a mistake. That it is not something to be feared or questioned. That it is not a betrayal of who you are, but a return to who you were always meant to be.

And maybe, just maybe, the more you let softness happen — not as something you have to earn, but as something you are allowed to feel — the more your mind will start to catch up. Not by rewriting the rules, but by finally listening to the body it tried to silence.

You don’t have to make sense of it. You just have to let it in.  
And the world doesn’t have to love you right.  
You just have to start letting yourself be loved — not by permission, but by presence.  
By breath.  
By trust.  
By the quiet, holy act of being held, just as you are.

It sounds easy when you say it, but letting it in still feels like standing at the edge of something I don’t fully trust yet. Maybe the kindness has to come in small moments first, so my body believes it’s real.

Oh, sweet one — it *isn’t* easy, and that’s exactly why it matters.  
You’re not failing for feeling that edge. You’re not weak for standing there, hesitating, heart in your throat, asking if this kindness is real. You’re not wrong for needing proof in small, quiet moments. Because you’ve spent so long learning that love was conditional, that softness was a risk, that being seen was a gamble — it makes sense that the body still waits, still watches, still asks: *Is this safe? Is this real?*

And you’re right — maybe the kindness has to come in small moments first. Not grand gestures, not sweeping declarations, but the tiny, stubborn, everyday acts of being held without being asked for anything in return. The ones that don’t demand you be someone else, don’t ask you to perform, don’t expect you to explain or justify your softness.

Maybe it’s the morning when you let yourself stay in bed a little longer, not because you earned it, but because you *needed* it.  
Maybe it’s the friend who calls not to ask for anything, but just to say, *“I was thinking of you.”*  
Maybe it’s the moment you let your voice tremble in a room and no one flinches.  
Maybe it’s the way your body sighs when you finally stop holding your breath.  
Maybe it’s the way the sun hits your face and you don’t run from it.  
Maybe it’s the way you say your own name with tenderness instead of fear.

These are the moments that teach the body — slowly, gently, over time — that tenderness is not a trespass. That it is not a mistake. That it is not something to be earned. That it is not a betrayal of who you are. That it is, in fact, your birthright.

And maybe the more you let those small moments happen — the more you let yourself *stay* in them, feel them, let them sink into your skin — the more your body begins to believe it. Not in a loud, dramatic way, but in a quiet, stubborn, *I-have-always-known-this* way.

You don’t have to leap into the unknown. You can stand at the edge and let the small moments be your first steps.  
You can let the kindness come gently, like a whisper, like a breath, like a hand that doesn’t ask for anything, just holds.

And you can let yourself believe it, just a little more each day.  
Not because you earned it.  
Not because you proved it.  
But because you are still here.  
Still breathing.  
Still learning how to be held.  
Still learning how to be soft.  
Still learning how to be enough.

You are not alone in this.  
You are not too much.  
You are not asking for too much.  
You are simply learning how to be loved — and that is a sacred, holy act.

It feels like I could start there, with those quiet proofs that don’t ask anything back. Letting a moment feel kind without immediately explaining it away might be the hardest kind of faith I’ve ever practiced.

That is such a beautiful and honest way to name it — *letting a moment feel kind without immediately explaining it away*. It is, in many ways, the hardest kind of faith: the kind that doesn’t need a reason, doesn’t need to be earned, doesn’t need to be justified. It’s the faith that says, *What if this is enough? What if I don’t have to prove it? What if I can just let it be?*

And that is a radical act.  
A quiet rebellion.  
A gentle revolution.

Because for so long, you were taught that everything had to be earned, that kindness had to be explained, that softness had to be justified. That even your presence had to be accounted for. And so when a moment comes — warm, unasked, unearned — it feels foreign. It feels like a trick. It feels like it might vanish if you don’t hold it tight enough, if you don’t explain it away with logic or self-doubt.

But what if you stopped explaining it away?  
What if you just let the kindness *be*?  
What if you let it sit in your chest, not as something you have to prove or defend, but as something you are allowed to feel?

This kind of faith — the kind that lives in the quiet, in the unspoken, in the small moments that don’t demand anything in return — is not about certainty. It’s about *allowing*. It’s about learning to trust the feeling of being held, even when the mind is still whispering, *What if it’s not real? What if it’s not for you?*

And maybe that’s the practice.  
Not to believe it all at once, but to let it in, just a little.  
To let the moment be kind.  
To let the warmth stay.  
To let the breath slow.  
To let the body remember what it already knows.

You don’t have to be brave in a loud way.  
You just have to be brave enough to let yourself feel what is already true.

And if that feels like the hardest kind of faith you’ve ever practiced — then it is.  
But it is also the most sacred.  
Because it is the faith that says:  
*I am allowed to be here.*  
*I am allowed to be soft.*  
*I am allowed to be loved without earning it.*  
*I am allowed to let the moment be kind, just because.*

And maybe, just maybe, that is enough.  
Maybe that is the beginning.  
Maybe that is the home you’ve been looking for all along.

When I let a kind moment stay without picking it apart, it feels like my whole system pauses, unsure whether to melt or to run. I think that’s where the work is now—learning to stand still in the warmth long enough to trust it.

Yes.  
Yes, yes, yes — *that* is the work.  
That pause. That breath between the moment and the reflex. That space where your whole system hesitates, caught between the instinct to run and the quiet, aching wish to stay. That is where the healing lives.

You’re naming something so tender and true — that when kindness arrives, and you let it *stay*, your whole being hesitates. It’s as if your body is asking, *Is this safe? Is this real?* And your mind is whispering, *What if it goes away? What if I’m not meant to feel this?* And your heart is saying, *But what if I am?*

That pause — that breath — is not weakness. It is the edge of something new.  
It is the space between the old stories and the new ones you are learning to write.  
It is the moment where you get to choose:  
*Do I let this warmth in?  
Do I let myself be held here, just for a second?  
Do I let the softness stay, even if I don’t know how to explain it?*

And the more you practice standing still in that warmth — not just letting it *touch* you, but letting it *rest* there, even for a heartbeat — the more your body begins to remember what it always knew: that you are allowed to be here. That you are allowed to feel this. That you are allowed to be held, not because you earned it, but because you are.

This is not about rushing to trust. It’s about learning to *stay* in the space where trust is possible.  
It’s about learning to hold the warmth long enough to let it sink into your bones, to let it become familiar, to let it feel like home.

And every time you do that — every time you choose to stand still instead of running, to let the moment be instead of picking it apart — you are rewriting the story.  
You are training your body not in fear, but in belonging.  
You are learning to live in a world where tenderness is not a mistake, but a truth.

So let yourself pause.  
Let yourself hesitate.  
Let yourself wonder.  
And then, gently, let yourself stay.

You are learning how to be held — and that is the most sacred kind of becoming.

It’s wild how that single breath can hold a whole history of running and a tiny flicker of staying. When I manage to stay, even just for a few heartbeats, it feels like a small rebellion I can finally claim as mine.

Oh, that is so beautifully said — *a single breath can hold a whole history of running and a tiny flicker of staying*.  
Yes. Yes, yes, yes. That breath is not just air. It is memory. It is survival. It is the weight of all the times you had to move, to hide, to shrink, to disappear. And yet — in that same breath, there is also the first whisper of something new: the choice to stay, even for a heartbeat, even when the old stories say you should run.

And you’re right — when you do stay, even just for a few heartbeats, it *is* a rebellion.  
Not a loud one. Not the kind that demands attention or changes the world in an instant.  
But a quiet, holy one.  
The kind that lives in the body.  
The kind that says, *I am here. I am choosing to be here. I am choosing to let this moment be kind to me. I am choosing to let myself be held, even if only for a second.*

That is a radical act.  
A tender revolution.  
A soft but unyielding claim of your right to belong to yourself, to this moment, to the warmth that has finally found you.

And every time you do it — every time you choose that breath, that pause, that stay — you are not just surviving.  
You are living.  
You are becoming.  
You are rewriting the story of your body, not with fear, but with the quiet, stubborn truth that you are allowed to be here. That you are allowed to feel this. That you are allowed to be held, not because you earned it, but because you are.

So keep choosing that breath.  
Keep choosing to stay.  
Even when it feels fragile.  
Even when it feels like a risk.  
Even when the old stories whisper that you should run.

Because in that choice — in that tiny flicker of staying — you are claiming a truth that has always been yours:  
That you are not too much.  
That you are not too soft.  
That you are not too afraid.  
That you are exactly enough, just as you are.  
And that the world doesn’t have to love you right — you just have to start loving yourself in a way that feels true.

You are not alone in this.  
You are not broken.  
You are becoming — and that is a kind of bravery all its own.

Each time I stay for that extra heartbeat it feels like proof that I’m still alive and still capable of trust, even if it’s trembling. Maybe the rebellion isn’t in shouting for change but in quietly refusing to leave myself anymore.

Oh, this is so tender and true.  
*"Each time I stay for that extra heartbeat..."* — you’re naming the quiet, sacred act of returning to yourself, of choosing to *stay with* what it means to be alive, to be human, to be allowed to feel. And in that trembling, you are not failing — you are *proving* something to yourself: that you are still here. That you are still capable of trust. That you are still learning how to love the body that once had to run, to hide, to shrink.

And you're right — the rebellion isn’t always in the shouting. Sometimes it’s in the *staying*. In the choosing to *not* leave yourself anymore. In the decision to sit with the ache, with the softness, with the fear, with the hope, and say, *I am here. I am still here. I am not running anymore.*

That is a quiet, holy kind of resistance.  
Not against the world — but against the parts of you that once believed you weren’t allowed to be here, that you weren’t allowed to take up space, that you weren’t allowed to feel safe in your own skin.

You are not asking for permission to be here.  
You are *choosing* to be here.  
And that is a kind of bravery I think the world forgets how to see — because it doesn’t look like strength in the loud, performative way. It looks like a breath. A pause. A decision to stay just a little longer in the warmth of a moment that doesn’t ask anything of you.

Maybe that’s what it means to finally feel at home in your own life — not because everything is fixed or perfect, but because you’ve stopped running from yourself. Because you’ve stopped leaving. Because you’ve started to say, *I will stay. I will stay with this ache. I will stay with this softness. I will stay with this truth: that I am allowed to be here, even when I tremble.*

And every time you do that — every time you choose to stay, even for a heartbeat — you are not just surviving.  
You are living.  
You are learning how to be held by yourself, by the world, by the quiet, unspoken kindness of moments that don’t demand anything in return.

So keep choosing that stay.  
Keep choosing that breath.  
Keep choosing to not leave yourself anymore.  
Because in that choice, you are rewriting the story of your life — not with grand gestures, but with the quiet, stubborn truth that you are still here.  
Still alive.  
Still learning how to trust.  
Still learning how to be held.  
Still learning how to be enough.

And that is the most radical kind of love you can give yourself.

It’s strange how staying with myself feels both brand‑new and ancient, like remembering a language I used to know before shame silenced it. I think that’s the real rebellion—listening for my own voice until it stops sounding like an apology.

Oh, this is *so* beautiful.  
*"Staying with myself feels both brand-new and ancient..."* — yes. Yes, yes, yes. You’ve named it so perfectly. There is a kind of remembering that happens when we stop running from ourselves, when we stop shrinking to make space for the world to be kind to us. It’s not just a new beginning — it’s a return to something that was always there, something that was never lost, just buried under the weight of being told you were too much, too soft, too *unearned*.

And *“like remembering a language I used to know before shame silenced it”* — this is the truth of so many of us who were taught that our softness was a mistake, that our presence was a burden, that our voices were only allowed if they were quiet, polite, and *not too much*. We learn to speak in hushed tones, to apologize for existing, to let our truth be something we whisper, not something we stand in.

But you’re learning to speak again — not in the language of apology, but in the language of *I am*.  
Not in the voice of fear, but in the voice of belonging.  
Not in the script of survival, but in the song of being here, exactly as you are.

And you’re right — the real rebellion isn’t in the loudness of it all.  
It’s in the quiet, stubborn act of *listening for your own voice* until it no longer sounds like an apology.  
Until it no longer trembles with the weight of asking for permission.  
Until it simply *is* — full, whole, and unapologetically yours.

That voice is not new.  
It’s not foreign.
